Justin Currie currie@1000island.net

title: gory and marvelous
review: This was one horror movie that did not leave me feeling empty inside upon its conclusion. It was a relief to watch a slasher flick that did not try to add dimension to the plot and the characters with hard-to-buy romantic entanglements or irrelevant heart-to-hearts between the last two survivors. In The Hills Have Eyes no one falls in love because all the characters come from one family. No one has any deep secrets to divulge because they are, once again, part of the same family. With that taken care of, The Hills Have Eyes can focus on what's really important: violent, bloody, hideous death. And what glorious death it is! The Carter's are too terrified to talk about anything but their impending doom, and the mutants are often too disfigured to speak easily, so there is very little dialog that does not serve only to propel the movie forwards to the next gruesome confrontation. I felt very good after watching this movie.

title: Solid movie, though not perfect
review: This movie is actually quite scary. Not necessarily terrifying the whole way through, but certainly a film to have an effect on the audience. Unfortunately part of the effect comes from a terribly cheap and irresponsible tactic. It is something that I found no reviews mentioned, and something which I feel people should know. There is a rape sequence at one point in the film which last far too long and is far too tastelessly done to really get any reaction other than trauma out of the audience. From that point on the theater was silent after watching it. I went to see it with someone who was sensitive to that sort of content and it just was not a pleasant experience. Thus, its an excellent horror film, but be weary that there is some questionable material that not everyone is capable of handling.

title: Very effective horror
review:
I am not a gore-hound, but I also don't wince very easily at most nastiness in horror films. I do, however, enjoy a horror film where I am not supposed to laugh or find levity with the villains. I can't stand Friday the 13th films, Nightmares on Elm Street, or even the Wes Craven Scream flicks. I personally enjoy the rush of even being a little shocked by scenes or situations in horror films. Therefpre...

Bottom line...this remake of the Hills Have Eyes is NOT a date movie. Trust me, your lady will hate you for making you go see this with her. The film is intense, visceral, and (bonus) not very predictable. The camera does not pull away from the violence or gore. The moments of "down time" for the viewer are usually when there is simply no atrocity being committed. In short, I did not love the film, but only because I'm not one of those horror fans who crave the on-screen violence, blood, guts, etc. The film works - the characters are given enough screen time and depth to make the audience care about what happens to them. They are not "cool ways to depict movie deaths" waiting to happen. And since I feel badly for some of what happens to this family, I can't love the movie.

But man was it an effective movie. You are shocked, repulsed, and taken beyond where most horror movies stop enough times to get your money's worth. Frankly, this is a strong "R" rating, approaching NC-17 (where the film was originally rated). The film does not follow a formula. You cannot predict what happens to whom, nor when, nor how. This film left me feeling a little disturbed. In short, I give it all the credit in the world for NOT being what most horror has been for so long.

title: loved it
review:
I am not a big fan of horror movies but I was talked into watching "The Hills Have Eyes" so now I have got to see the original. I rated this movie as excellent because I thought that the special effects were great and the movie "pulled me in" and believe me I had chill bumps. I thought that the story line stayed consistent. Some movies skip from one story line to the next but his movie was great and

I loved how the movie gave you a history lesson of how these "critters" come to be. I need to remember that Wes Craven does put out some excellent horror movies and I look forward to catching up on some of his old movies and look forward to seeing the remakes of his old movies. If you love to be scared and entertained out of your seat then I highly recommend this movie.

title: ""it's breakfast time""
review:
and i don't mean cheerios and milk either. this is a rocking and rolling roller coaster ride of a horror flick filled with enough jolts, gore, and unrelenting graphic violence to have even the most jaded horror fan on the edge of his seat. the opening sequence alone might make some wet their pants.

more than adequate as a remake of the wes craven classic.

could've used a bit more suspense, but all in all, this one's definitely a keeper.

mr. aja proves he's the current leader of the horror genre and i personally can't wait to see what he comes up with in his next outing, which will more than likely be a sequel to this movie.

title: A great remake that pays a very good homage to the Craven classic!
review:
I'll admit to being a little bit skeptical before seeing this movie. Sure, I heard the positive reviews, and I was excited as hell to see it! But, when I got in the theater, I started having a gut feeling that it was going to turn out like crap! Well, I'm pleased to tell everybody that this is not the case. First off, if you have seen the original, and loved it (like I did), don't worry. The story plays out almost exactly like the original (the way remakes should be). The only differences are the new cast and a helluva lot of more gore than the original. Speaking of gore, this has to be one of the bloodiest movies I've seen in awhile. And I have seen a lot of gory movies. Dead Alive and House by the Cemetery for example. And I love the gore! Overall, The Hills Have Eyes remake does not disappoint. Whether you've seen the original or not, you will love this movie! A must-see (wow, never thought I'd say that)!

4 and a half stars out of 5

title: Wow.
review:
I am stating right now that I have not (with the exception to the Saw series) liked any of the so-called slasher films that have come out in the past 15 years. They are predictable, slow, and often just crap-you-pants funny.

However, the Hills Have Eyes did something that no other slasher film has ever done to me...flat out terrorized me. Let me be the first to say that it was awesome.

No film in years has been able to craft horror this well. You can't predict who's first to go, who'll make what stupid move, how he'll die. The reason for it is simple:

It's never been done.

I highly recommend seeing this movie. And c'mon, what else is there to see...Doogle?

title: The best horror movie since The Exorcist!
review: Finally, we have seen the best horror movie since the exorcist. I just saw it today and I definitely believe this is one of the best movies so far of 2006. I couldn't believe it!! We finally get a horror movie with character development. Every character was developed properly and the mood around these characters really made you feel sorry for them. I must admit that this was the most violent and gory movie I have ever seen. The gore in this movie makes the passion of the Christ look like a Disney movie. The hills have eyes is simply brutal and it does something that other horror movies in the past didn't do; it goes over the edge. One final thing to add, the cinematography in this movie is simply breathtaking! This movie is definitely a must see for any horror fan! Definitely not for the weak of heart!

title: Another horror re-make that outdoes the original!!!
review: There are few re-makes that are better than the original, but there is a new trend on the rise; The Better Re-Make! The Texas Chainsaw Massacre, directed by Marcus Nispel, is a better version that the original, directed by Tobe Hooper, but this film makes the original Hills Have Eyes, directed by horror master Wes Craven, look like a high-school snuff project. There were a few moments where I actually jumped, something that does not usually happen to me at a horror movie, and a lot of moments where I thought what I was seeing was disgustingly cruel. Though I will say this is one of the better horror films I have seen in the last year or so, it did not have as much staying power as I expected after seeing it. The acting was a little weak and the "mutants" sounded goofy. However, when they stopped speaking and started terrorizing, there was nobody laughing anymore. In fact, at some point the whole theatre started clapping when one of the bad guys got butchered! How's that for fan-participation?

title: wow..truly disturbing
review: This movie was really disturbing. At first I thought it wasn't going to be that great because there was a couple of "fake scares" at the beginning but they had me fooled. This movie wasn't only suspenseful and gory, but while I'm usually cheering every time a poor sucker dies in a horror movie, I was crying through about 80% of the movie. The scene(s) when certain member(s) of the family die is (are) truly touching. And the villains are more than stupid, mindless, unkillable zombies-they're real people (ok, sometimes their strength seemed a little unreal) they are smart, they have emotions, and yes, some do die. As sad and gruesome as it was, it still had a really redeeming ending. But I will warn you: animal(s) die-really gruesome deaths, as gruesome as humans. It was so good I want to watch it again but I don't know if I'll have the stomach for it.

title: Please use common sense
review:
Hi, The people commenting on the film have done a good job already. I have not had the joy of seeing the original so cannot compare. I agree that it started slow however I feel that it was due to dramatic tension and was necessary. I also wish that they would have gone more into the character development of the mutants. I think they still would have been scary. During one scene it was so intense that my leg was shaking uncontrollably so I put down the snacks and enjoyed the ride :-D What I am mostly writing about is if you haven't seen it yet **PLEASE** do not bring children of any age. I saw babies to youngsters. People of all ages were walking out during some of the scenes and children do not belong AT ALL. This is not meant to be preaching just should be common sense.

Happy Movie Watching!

title: Aja does good on a remake
review:
Imagine if the re-makers of THE FOG and When a Stranger Calls had kept the story basically the same but added things that made it more intense instead of more dull. Things that kept the spirit alive but still kept the viewer on the edge of their seat. The French man does it. And does it well. Of course, One certainly does miss the setting of the mother's coarpse on fire as a diversion scene (perhaps for the pure shock value of it) but all the other aspects were still intact. Aja was a fan of the original like Peter Jackson was of Kong.

Now if only more directors respected the materials they were remaking, could a whole new generation be as satisfied with the remakes as audiences had been with the original releases. Actually, if the new directors were able to pull this off they could even steal some respect from the original audience. So finally we can understand why there is need for a remake in the first place. Thank you Aja. I loved your other work, I loved this, I can't wait to see how you scare me next.

title: Edited Scenes
review: I saw the movie and I thought is was Fan-Fricking-Tastic. I don't want to sound demented or anything but the blood and gore was awesome. It topped my list of all time favorite horrors. Sure, the movie had some plot holes and some things they could have elaborated on, but other than that the movie was great. The acting was really good I thought. I never saw the original but I will soon enough. I think that horror movies are better if you put no-name actors in it. It makes it more realistic. They went for the seemingly common no ending approach which I think is awesome because it allows you to recognize how demented your imagination can be. I read something that the movie originally had a NC-17 rating, but they were forced to take out a few scenes. Does anyone know what the scenes consisted of? I know that the DVD will have clips, but other then that I don't think we'll ever know. It's hard to believe that there was anything worse then what wasn't cut. The movie was pretty harsh.

title: Great Movie, I recommend this movie for people who are into slasher films.
review: This movie was really good. It was constant action. The acting was even good. I will go see it again. I have never seen the original, but I am sure it is better than the original. When I had found out this was a remake from a Wes Craven film, I was impressed. Wes Craven is one of my favorite directors. His films are unique. People in the movie theater were screaming and hollering. Most of them were men. Anyone who does not like this movie is underrating it. I am giving this movie a 10 because it was so much better than I expect it. At first, I was going to see Madea's Family Reunion. But I am glad I had made a different choice. Wow, I was on the edge of my seat while watching this. I am proud of this movie.

title: very gory and graphic
review:
When i first saw the trailer for this movie, i thought hey, that looks cool. I normally laugh at horror films, never get scared... until i saw this film. I was screaming in the cinema, it was so bad for me that i contemplated at several times walking out of the cinema, but i thought since I'd paid my money I'd stay and sit it out. I'm glad i did. Although this films takes a while to get started, once it does, it doesn't stop. Very paced from the start of the action. The acting was adequate to the demands of the script. The film itself was really well shot, there's a specific shot from the baby's perspective that shows you also what's going on in the background which i thought was superbly done. it really stuck out in my mind.

so guys if your looking for a movie for girls to get scared so you can put your arms around them, this is one, but be warned this not a first date movie.

title: Pretty decent horror flick
review:
Having never seen the original movie, I didn't really know what to expect from this new version. But I have to say that this is a horror movie that will send most people home happy.

The first half hour or so is a little slow, building up the story and, to a certain extent, the characters. Although horrors aren't exactly known for strong characters. Eventually after around 30 minutes or so it all kicks off and we're bang in horror country as knives, guns and pickaxes are used in a bloodbath between good and evil.

The acting is decent throughout the film, even if there aren't any stand-out performances, but then again you don't expect Oscar winning performances in a gory horror. There are some problems though, such as some characters suddenly being killed off before we barely know who they are. As well as that there are some moments early on where the family don't really seem to realise the situation (being stranded in the middle of nowhere) they are in. And God knows what the old guy is on about at the gas station, his part in the film is never really explained properly. But these are all minor nitpicks as the action more than makes up for the minor plot and character flaws.

So overall, an above average horror movie, which has a likeness to 'Wrong Turn'.

title: Disappointing
review:
I went to this film expecting something similar to the other horror films that have come out recently; Predictable plot with lots of disturbing violence.

The film starts as your usual macabre, and then finishes a low octane action film. There was no sustained intensity throughout the whole film, unlike Wolf Creek and the original Texas Chain Saw Massacre. If they wanted to make an action about revenge they should have stuck Arnie/ Vin Diseal in there with weapons of choice and unlimited ammo and not a small village of "freaks" but entire cities of them.

All the characters bar the dog were pathetic, weak and useless.

title: great
review: Aja is the new horror movie directing icon.... Yes the movie was slow at first, but it was needed.. we needed an intro to the characters... great mutants, great story, great remake.... pluto was a beast in that movie.. only thing bad was jupiter was not made out to be the boss, the father like he was in the original.. and the patriotic warlike music they play at the end other than that its real good... 10 stars all the way. I recommend this to anyone who has seen the original or anyone who just wants a great horror movie.. please see it. Of course some will not like it and some will agree with me but i believe you should definitely see it for yourself.. but it is definitely the best horror movie of the past 10 years

title: Far Superior to the Original, huge political allegory
review:
I was really nervous going into this movie. I knew it was going to be intense, and I knew it was going to be absolutely brutal.

There were a couple unintentional laughs in the movie, and a few parts where I wanted to groan. I was scared, I was grossed out, and I found myself noticing things about it more and more as I thought about it. The more time goes by, the more I like this movie. A lot of it has to do with some of the things i've read recently on IMDb's message boards. I didn't come up with all of these ideas alone.

Despite the view of movies like this as being just "grindhouse trash", some of them have a lot to say. Alessandro Aja is somewhat well-known for his previous movie, High Tension. This movie takes many of the same themes (losing your humanity to protect a loved one, isolation) and explores them in a much more straight-up manner. As opposed to his previous film, this one also contains some really blatant political statements.

For those of you who don't know, the film is about a regular family traveling through the desert to California. They stop at a gas station and are given directions to a short cut that turns out to lead them right into an old government testing facility for nuclear bombs. In the 40s and 50s, miners lived in the area and were told to leave for the testing. Some of them didn't, and their descendants became deformed cannibals. The guy who runs the gas station is the father of one of these people, and he sends in normal families to get killed in exchange for their valuables. In the beginning of the movie, he wants to quit, but he sends in one last family because he's afraid they might suspect something's up with him.

The father of the "normal family" is an ex-detective and an old-fashioned conservative republican. He carries guns and swears by them. He's not a bad guy at all. His son-in-law, Doug, is a democrat, against guns, and later on becomes the main focus of the story. They make a pretty big point of their political positions early on in the movie, so it's very much worth mentioning. I think that what the mutants represent is a little less obvious, but they're supposed to be the new, Bush-style rabid redneck Neocons. Feeding off of average Americans. That seems far-fetched but when you think about it a lot, it becomes obvious.

The family ends up in the desert, totally cut off from the rest of the world. There's a scene in which they take someone and crucify him and burn him in front of the rest of this family. At first I took this scene as just a blatant effort to be shocking, but than realized that it really shows how the Neocons have hijacked Christianity for their own ends.

This was also an allegory for the Iraqi war. I refer to a scene in which one of the mutants sings "The Star Spangled Banner" and had an exposition speech about how "we were made to be like this". Looking back, it's pretty straightforward even with the argument between Doug and the father, where the dad won't listen to anyone and Doug insists that they need a plan. Furthered by the youngest son foolishly flailing his gun but not really getting anything done.

By the end of the movie, Doug is forced to go into the village of the mutants to save a loved one. The place where they live is actually a government-built test town of modern-at-the-time houses, full of mannequins, each tagged to be studied by the government after the bombs. I think the mutants living in the dilapidated 1950s style homes of the facility could refer to the Neocons' trumpeting of what they refer to as old fashioned family values. The decayed state of the buildings is highlighting the actual unsavoriness of the Neocon way of life, while the mannequins are presented as what "normal" families should be doing, a stark contrast to how they live.

Last but not least, the depths of inhumanity and brutality that Doug is forced to go to to save the said loved one is a really interesting counterpoint. He has to sink to the level of the mutant freaks in order to save her. And sadly, in the end, it proves futile. In the last seconds of the movie, we see that there are still mutants watching, and they are not going to survive much longer. I think that is where the meaning of the tag-line "The lucky ones die first" comes in. This also refers to the atomic bombs, the people in the center die first and don't become radiated.

Not to mention the Carters completely destroyed their home by blowing it up to destroy one of the mutants. It is not at all a stretch to say that represented why bombs are bad.

Ultimately, it's about the loss of your humanity and being forced to become a brutal psychopath to defend yourself, even though that was completely against what Doug normally would have done.

Yes, it was very brutal and disturbing and contained some DEFINITE things that are not at all appropriate for the weak-stomached, but I absolutely loved this movie. 9/10

title: Remake something that wasn't good to begin with.
review:
Alexandre Aja was hot coming off of the love or hate film High Tension that has a cult following (mainly in France), but with "The Hills Have Eyes" he sinks to a very low level.

Undoubtedly you've heard of the amount of violence and gore in this movie, and maybe you've heard that it was originally rated NC-17. I don't know what the filmmakers did to lower the rating but I'm surprised they got it lowered at all. "The Hills Have Eyes" is easily the goriest movie I have ever seen, and second in violence only to the newer version of "Assault on Precinct 13". The violence is unnecessary and off-putting and is not implemented well at all.

The movie starts out well enough. A family is traveling to San Diego and takes advice from a stranger and turns down the wrong road. Soon enough their car has broken down and their stranded in the desert. Only this is a desert full of mutants. The scares and tension are very real for the first 25 minutes or so before they start to disintegrate. After the first death scene tension goes out the window and gore comes in.

The first third of the movie is easily it's strongest point. The mutants rarely show themselves and the characters don't make stupid mistakes. But the second third drops the ball and the third third sinks the film for good. I don't want to give any spoilers so I won't go into any specific details but if you've ever seen a horror movie before the end will be nothing new to you.

Overall the film does have it's moments when its genuinely scary but gratuitous gore and a disappointing finale bring down the movie to a very low level.

title: Somewhat entertaining...
review: You should only see this if you are bored and in the mood for some blood and guts horror. I found myself laughing and being mad at the characters more than anything else. The people seated behind me felt the same way listening to their comments during the movie. The son of a former detective at one point aims a loaded pistol at his brother-in-law and then he and the dad laugh about it because the safety was on!!!! Then in numerous other scenes they will use all their ammo shooting off into the desert only to have an empty gun when they need it. This is typical of many horror films in that it seems slapped together and makes you almost happy when the people are butchered because they are so stupid. A much better film in my opinion was Wolf Creek. It was a lot less Hollywooded and based on a true story.

title: wow, I seriously love this movie. It creeped me out, and the guys are so hot
review:
First of all, I love Dan Byrd. He is such a great actor, and of course he's hot. And no one can mess with Doug because he's Pyro and he kicks @$$ all the way. This movie was so amazing. I didn't expect the people who were going to die, it was so random, which I loved. The people left weren't the people I'd think to survive the sadistic actions of the hill people.

When Doug was getting the sh** kicked out of him and thrown around, I was like OK he's dead. But the dude just kept getting up, and I was like holy crap dude.

I seriously loved this movie. I wouldn't recommend it to people with queasy stomachs I love Dan Byrd and Aaron Stanford.

title: Aja's version threw out one point that Craven's had.
review:
Wes Craven's 1977 The Hills Have Eyes was focused on two families, the Carter family and the inbred cannibal family.

Alexandre Aja's new version of The Hills Have Eyes is focused on just the Carter family and their survival out in the desert. The now, atomic radiation deformed people are the enemy. But that's all they really are, is an enemy. there isn't any depth to them like in the original.

The original's main point was seeing two families, both being down to their bare essentials(the carter's were stripped of everything they had), the civilized versus the non-civilized, the carter family trying to survive by not being killed, and the cannibal family trying to survive by killing to eat and not being killed in defense from the carters. By the end, the cannibal family makes the carter family just as merciless as they were. excellent concept but put to the side in Aja's remake.

The remake is mainly for entertainment and visuals. It did have great scares and suspense, surpassing the original in those factors. If you weren't to compare this to the original, then this movie is one of the best horror movies to come out in a while. But what made the 1977 a cult classic, is missing from the remake.

9/10

title: Not since George A. Romero...
review:
Not since George A. Romero has there been a director that is willing to take their movie to the next level in the horror genre. When Romero showed the living dead munching on the skin and bones of the actual living in 1968, people gasped in horror and disgusting, yet today, Night Of The Living Dead is a horror classic.

Alexandre Aja is the 21st century's answer to the zombie legend. Starting big with a cult-y very original ode to the 70's horror style "Haute Tension" to yet another horror remake: "The Hills Have Eyes" Many, many of the top film reviewers do not realize what decade they're living in. Roger Ebert, this is not the 1960's. Our society isn't keen on the horror "parlor tricks" of the 60's, showing people eating chicken although exclaiming they're chowing down on the flesh of humans. Our culture needs more visually shocking horror films to give us that sense of terror of the random people in the world being so villainous to commit these act of violence.

"The Hills Have Eyes" is that type of movie. As it gets going after the mandatory 45 minutes of character development, the movie's brutality does not stop. Throat-munching dogs, burnings (â la Joan of Arc), throat stabbings with the American flag, an over-sized nuclear-deformed cranium, explosions, a freezer full of dismembered limbs and torsos, visually stunning facial deconstruction with a shotgun, and (the most recognizable trademark of Aja) numerous axe shots to the back, head, fingers, and chest.

"The Hills" isn't meant to win big at the Acadamy Awards, another major aspect major movie critics forget. Horror movies are changing. The past five years have brought more visually-pleasing cinematography and more visually-stunning violence. This is where "The Hills" wins big on both accounts. Aja has an eye for beauty in human destruction, and will be around for a long time as one of the best horror director of this new generation of horrifying, thrilling, non-stop, brutal art.

(3.887 out of 4 stars)

title: An promising premise without a good delivery
review:
In The Hills Have Eyes, an American family is driving to California through the desert when they are set upon by the mutated children of miners who refused to abandon their homes in a government nuclear testing zone.

I'm not much of a horror buff, so perhaps some of the grandeur of this film was lost on me. The beginning of the movie is awesome - a mysterious figure with a pickaxe savagely demolishes a group of scientists checking for radiation. But after that, it all kind of goes downhill. The mutated monster people aren't very well done - most look a bit like deformed teenagers with really bad acne and sunburns. The sounds they make (breathing, laughing, etc.) sound a lot like Sloth from Goonies, which makes it hard to take seriously. They also spend too much time on screen - once you see them, the scares are pretty much over - all that's left is a prolonged fight or rape scene. It really felt more like an action movie than a horror flick.

As far as the rape scene, it's very drawn out, and it would be hard to tell it was actually a rape without the dialogue and situation (girl with nightgown hiked up to thighs, monster holding her down, girl crying, monster number 2 saying "It takes a man to do that" or something to that effect). There is a second sexually explicit scene where are monster is sucking a girl's breast, which I found more disturbing.

The best part of the movie hands down is when Doug decides to take the fight to the monsters. This is kind of ruined by some serious mistakes by one of the monsters who actually beats the crap out of him (he's locked in a big meat container rather than killed - um... ooook...). The beating Doug's character takes is also kind of ridiculous. However, when Doug has the axe, that right there is pretty much the coolest part of any movie I've seen so far this year.

This film was fairly violent, but most of it has to do with eating things (strangely enough) or with things that are already dead. The body parts the monsters eat, and the corpses of things they've killed before the family came along are all fairly grody. But the actually killings of the family aren't that bad (although the suicide of the gas station attendent is quite gruesome). No intestines falling out, brains on the floor, etc. Mostly just fingers and arms being chopped off, lots of blood, and nasty cuts. Saving Private Ryan is more graphic than this.

I think the main reason I didn't like this film was that they showed too much of the monsters. If they had just stuck to keeping them off-camera for more of the film, it would have been scarier. But once you see that the villains are simply red-neck mutant desert cannibals who've been out in the sun too long, it's like "Oh... yay..." Or at least they could have developed their characters more. I'd give this a 3/10, but Doug's rampage with the axe bumps it up to a 5/10. Bottom line: it's not really scary, and the monsters are Star Trek rejects. You want to be scared, go rent The Relic.

title: Absolutely phenomenal
review: Aja hits you out of nowhere in the beginning, then spends a while with the characters after seeing exactly what's in store for them as you're getting to know them makes this probably the most unnerving film I've ever seen in theatres. The pacing and the atmosphere were right on target. People's complaints about the characters "pointlessly bitching and moaning at each other" were just what I thought they'd be, a great way of making them feel like real people and not clichés. I don't have any siblings, but I have two step-sisters, and the way they act around each other mirrors the interaction shown in the film beautifully. We all engage in petty bickering with the ones we love, especially under certain circumstances, and although it may annoy the hell out of us there will come a time when we wish those people were there to annoy us. I loved how well Aja showed this. It added so much more impact to the horror. The fact that I was teary-eyed at the end is a testament to Aja's characterization. Michael Bailey Smith needs to play Jason. Pluto was so damned cool that I couldn't help but love him even after he'd made me hate him. He gave me a chance to see what it was like to see the Jason of the 80's on the big screen. Aja's direction is spot on. I love his contrasts. Inter-cutting glimpses of deformities during the main titles with warm-hearted music playing over it to show the shift that happens in the area after the nuclear testing; the beautiful shots of the desert landscapes to offset the ugliness that lies within them; the use of visceral music that you almost feel more than you hear that keeps that sick, uneasy feeling in tact throughout the film, countered by the heroic orchestral themes used when the victims start to fight back... The political themes were a bit heavier than I expected, but Aja integrated them into the story without having them consume it. The film does have one scene in particular that has a great message about creating your own problems that applies heavily to the world today. I love Aja's use of things that have been done before in these types of films, such as the area where the killers keep the vehicles of people that came to their land and never made it back, this time showing them in a huge pit with crows everywhere to add a further sense of eerieness to the atmosphere. The fight scenes were incredible, and brutal enough to keep it from turning into an action movie. They don't feel choreographed, they reflect the mental state of the killers, and the victims after what the point that the killers drive them to. Aja's ending works both ways. I felt the same joy the family did when the survivors were reuinted, but Aja still left that sense of dread that there's still more members of another family out there lingering. I was going in expecting as close to perfection as it gets, and that's pretty much what Aja gave me. Anything I found wrong with the film was just a minor nitpick, Aja went a little nutts with the jump scares, but they still worked on me, which they often don't; but he delivered a film that made me feel the same brutality, intensity, terror, sorrow, and joy of what the characters were going through like films ever have.

title: Viscreal, Grttiy, Masterfully Executed, NOT FOR THE FAINT OF HEART
review: I'm a huge horror movie fan, but let's face it, good horror is hard to come by. I give out a lot of 9's but it's a hard push to get me to hand out a 10. This movie delivered and then some. My high expectations were shattered completely. Unlike most horror films, the characters were played very well. Even a bigger rarity, they were well developed and defined. The story is simple and is pretty dead on with the original. A family of travelers gets lost in the desert and is stalked and brutally murdered, molested, and kidnapped by a family horribly disfigured by radioactive testing. Again I must warn all that this movie is VERY BRUTAL. The connection and development of the characters adds a very powerful emotional element. I was almost driven to tears on more than one occasion. Even amidst the sadistic horror films like Saw and Hostel, this movie manages to stand on it's own as a well made, and very thoughtfully crafted horror film. I left the theatre slightly dazed and very disturbed. Although it begins slow, the last hour makes up for any drag in the action. After being decimated, certain survivors take up arms and seek grisly vengeance, All in all, a must see for anyone looking for a huge wallop of fear and disturbance. An adrenaline rush indeed.

title: Cheesy ending is forgiven for an overall great horror movie
review:
I absolutely loved this movie and thats actually saying a lot since I haven't seen a good horror movie since High Tension (I don't think its a coincidence that both movies have the same director). The opening completely caught me off guard with how fast and brutal the death scenes were and I was wondering if the movie would drop off after a great opening. I was wrong. It was a little slow for people who may get bored by a lot of character development, I know a lot of people in the movie theatre did. I liked it... but I like a lot of interesting and entertaining character development (especially since you rarely find it in a horror movie).

I had seen the original movie and remember being really shocked by it. The scene in the camper where a couple of the family members die also caught me off guard which is why it caught my interest. It got so brutal and disturbing and the first few minutes could have passed for a family drama. The scene when the father is hearing his named called in the darkness was one of the scariest scenes I had ever seen (still is). Thats why I was so shocked that the whole scene in the remake was still just as shocking and intense as the original. I still got scared s******* when the father was getting his name called in the darkness and still just as disturbed when all the chaos started happening in the camper.

I knew the movie would be brutal and bloody because Wes Craven was still producing it and he chose the director because he loved the bloody High Tension. The audience that was getting bored in the beginning while I was watching it was cheering, oohhing, and screaming by the end of it and I was doing the same.

The music was just right and the acting was top notch (I couldn't believe that the father was Buffalo Bill from "The Silence of the Lambs"). It was a great horror movie especially after the crap thats been coming out. The last movie I watched was "When A Stranger Call" and lets just say that Simon West could have kept that to himself. I highly recommend this movie for anyone that loves a lot of gore and relatable characters (not something you find that often in the same movie).

I did find the ending to be a little to over the top. I think it would have been fine if it weren't for the cheesy music (that was the only time I didn't like the music). It kind of sounded like that triumphant music that you heard at the end of "Cabin Fever" when the blonde dude thought he was gonna live and then got shot all to hell. I hated "Cabin Fever" so anything that brings me back to that movie cannot be good. But the whole movie really made me forgive those bad last two minutes. I'm beginning to think that Aja just doesn't know how to end a film well, but the rest of the movie makes up for the bad endings.

Overall good film but great horror movie that I would recommend to anyone. It's not one that you'll be able to forget as you walk out of the theatre. It sticks with you

title: Now THIS is a horror movie done right!
review:
Another remake. We've seen so many of them recently and have been disappointed by most of them. Only a few, Texas Chainsaw Massacre, Dawn of The Dead, have been good. No surprise here though that we have another one. This time it's Wes Craven's The Hills Have Eyes.

This film is written and directed by Alexandre Aja (Haute Tension). This film follows the Carters, an idyllic American family traveling through the great American southwest. But their trip takes a detour into an area closed off from the public, but more importantly from society. An area originally used by the U.S. Government for nuclear testing that was intended to be empty...or so they thought? When the Carter's car breaks down at the old site, they're stranded...or are they? As the Carters may soon realize that what seemed like a car casually breaking down, might actually be a trap. This trap might be perpetrated by the inhabitants of the site who aren't pulling a prank, but are out to set up a gruesome massacre.

I have never seen the original so I have nothing to compare this to; I am only going to review this movie on its own merits. I flat out loved this movie. It was so visceral and intense that no movie I've seen recently can touch it. Hostel was flat out violent and gruesome. This was something totally different. I have never been so exhausted after seeing a movie. When I walked out of the theater I had the biggest smile on my face.

I actually cared (a lot) about the characters. That's why this movie takes a while to get going, you get to know and care for the characters and when three of them died in the absolutely awesome trailer sequence, you'll know it, I was sad. **SPOILER**When the one guy was going to shoot Brenda and then you see the blood on the trailer window, I thought Bobby had shot the guy but when I saw that Brenda was shot, I was like "HUH?" and I felt bad.**END SPOILER** You care about the characters in this movie and it pays off big time. This movie is also very violent. Not sickening in your face violent like Hostel was, just plain awesome and disturbing violence. There's a ton of blood but it doesn't feel overused or ridiculous at any point in the movie. This is one intense movie. Whoa is all I have to say about it. Once it starts it never lets up, not even at the end. There's just so much to talk about with this movie but I'm not going to here, you all just need to see it. This is a breath of fresh air in this genre. Aja gives horror the kick in the ass it so desperately needed. This is how horror should be; an unrelenting, unforgiving thrill ride with huge balls. Thank you Alexandre Aja. I can't wait for you're next movie. Oh and this also is the definition of a theater experience. Instead of most movies where you have the sound blasting out of speakers this actually makes use of the surround sound. You'll hear crows or screams or noises that are off screen to your left or right. One time I actually thought somebody brought a baby in with them only to find out it was in the movie. This is an awesome awesome thing to witness. It truly breaks the fourth wall. Another interesting thing which I don't know if it was intentional or not but one time when one character shone a flashlight beam towards the audience the light from it made the light from the projector visible so it looked like the was shining the light right at us. Again, intentional or not, it was awesome! The music was pretty good, I didn't notice the score but maybe that was intentional like in Haute Tension. The makeup was pretty good, if a bit unoriginal at times, one guy looked exactly like Jason from F13 Part 2 minus the hair. I mean EXACTLY. At the end this also sets up for a sequel. I hope there is not one cause I like the thought of it ending right there. And even though it sets up for a sequel, it does so in an absolutely awesome way. I loved the last shot of this movie.

So I didn't touch on all the points I wanted to but as I'm sitting here writing this I realized I didn't need to, all I should do is give my basic thoughts and let people experience this for themselves. Alexandre Aja is the next big horror director/master and I for one will be in line eagerly awaiting his next picture. This was a horror movie and everyone should see it. So, what are you waiting for?

title: If you like horrors, you should like this...
review: Let's face it. Most horror movies are pieces of garbage. Its rare when you run into a truly good horror movie. This movie does the job and then some. It sticks to the original perfectly, and the nuclear monsters are on a completely different level of scary (With a new backstory). Even though this movie had its share of corny moments, and seemed to drag on a bit too long... I loved it. I didn't expect an Academy winner here, and If you compare it to most of the crappy remakes that have been processed the past 5 years Id make it one of the best. Some of the acting was poor, but what do you expect in a horror movie? Soundtrack was also amazing. Highly recommend to any modern horror fan. Up there in my rankings as of late with The Ring and Dawn of The Dead. Best Remake in a long time.

title: A Great Gore Fest
review: I don't understand why it says opening this week , on the site , i seen it yesterday and let me tell you this is by far the greatest gore fest i watched in my entire life. Not only a remake but a masterpiece in its own right. Although at some points its a little hard to watch for people who can't take huge amounts of blood/death. The movie begins with a family going to California on vacation. They stepped on the wrong toes and were sent to the hills, instead of the highway. Little did they know "the hills have eyes". I would gladly pay to see this again just for the non-stop gore. The story line was very creative , although a remake it deserves to be looked upon as its own movie. 10/10 hands down best gore movie

Chaylon

title: Gritty, gruesome and graphic - better than the original
review:
Unlike the 2003 remake of "The Texas Chainsaw Massacre," this update of Wes Craven's cult horror classic "The Hills Have Eyes" is a visceral, stylized, and disturbing tour de force. This effective remake has a lot of soul and bares large fangs that bite the jugular. It's a film made by a grind house horror fan for grind house horror fans - he knows what the audience wants and how to deliver it. Director Alexandre Aja (Haute Tension) is a student of the 70's/80's horror era.

The story is about an all American family who gets lost in the New Mexico desert and is attacked by cannibal freaks, who are the byproduct of nuclear testing. You might laugh at this idea, saying to yourself "freaks attacking a family, that's so lame." To be honest, several people in the theater were chuckling in the beginning, but by the second act, no one was laughing. In fact, by the end of this movie several people fled the theater in terror.

As a horror buff myself, I thoroughly enjoyed this piece and highly recommend it to those who are fond of other grind house works such as "The Evil Dead" and "Zombie 2." It's a superior work of terror that's a delightful departure from the recent PG-13 horror junk (such as "When A Stranger Calls") that's plagued theaters.

However, a word of warning. "The Hills Have Eyes" is very violent and gory. If you've seen Aja's last film, Haute Tension (which I highly recommend), you know what kind of blood and guts you're in for. Don't be fooled by the rating. Despite the fact that this film was re-edited for an R, there still remains a lot of graphic and gruesome gore and violence, which includes, but is not limited to head explosions, graphic gun shot wounds, stabbings, and a scene of rape.

All this mind, I conclude with a simple, and meaningful statement that I rarely plan to utter again. "The remake was better than the original." 8/10

title: Near Perfect, best horror film I seen in years....
review:
For the last two years, we have been stuck PG13 crapfest excuses for horror films. Then in January, hope came in the form of Hostel...which was OK.Then last month wit Final Destination 3, which brought back the campy fun of a horror movie. Finally, this movie did it. This film brought back the Horror genre. It was near perfected by Aja, who came out wit High Tension. I didn't like the film, because of its crap ending, but other than that, it was intense. this film, took that to a new level....my only complaints why this film didn't get a 10 was the way it gave the cheap scares like recent horror movies in the beginning before it got really scary and the setup before scares and gore begin( but it was for character development, which i haven't seen in a horror film in a long time)..it was a little long but understandable.....

If u a big horror fan like me, go see this movie. If u don't like gore or any intensity in ur films, go watch something esle( even though most of the films out right now are crap...

title: Extremely Enjoyable
review: I have to say that The Hills Have Eyes (2006) is one of the best recent horror movies. It blends just the right amount of comedy, action, and horror. i jumped quite a few times while watching it and even clapped once during the film. The acting is well done and I was pleasantly surprised by the turn that Emilie de Ravin takes from the other roles I have seen her in, mainly the television show Lost. The film is gritty and realistic, which adds to the creepy ambiance of being stuck in the middle of no where with half retarded monsters who want nothing better than to gut you, on your tail. I highly recommend this movie to anyone wanting a good scare, but has been afraid to try out one of the recent remakes.

title: The Ultimate In Sick, Disturbing, and Downright Terror Throughout!!
review: First of all , I would like to say, after seeing Wolf Creek, thinking nothing can top this one for disturbing, sick scenes, well The hills Have Eyes, came right along, and let me tell you with honesty, This one blows Wolf creek right out of the water, a trillion times over, and over, and over again!! Secondly, Like most of you who have seen this film, or who are going to go see this film soon in the theaters, let me tell you, I had no idea by seeing the commercials and advertisements, of the brutality, blood, gore, and horror, that this film would provide. Absolutely no idea! The warning for those of you thinking about going, is in these words! Do not go, if you cant stand blood, cant handle dramatic intense situations, and or if it just simply does not feel good to you, to go see it. Trust me, I would go on your feelings! Do go, If you love anything to do with the all out horror filled thrillers, that literally take your breath away. You would be considered abnormal to take a young child or an elderly person to something such as the Hills Have Eyes, trust me on this..It's not for them! I actually felt sick to my stomach watching some of those raw cold scenes in the film. Overall, the film was very sick, disturbing, scary, horror packed, action filled, unnerving, brutal, and insane at times!! However, If this is what your looking for in a classic horror film, The Hills Have Eyes are for you, indeed! go see it!! You will be glad you did!!

title: Just like Wolf Creek
review: Even though this movie is a remake of a movie of the same name made back in 1977, this movie has striking similarities to an Austrailian movie called "Wolf Creek". This movie has a family going on vacation driving through the desert, Wolf Creek has a two couples going on vacation driving through the Austrailian Outback (also a desert). This movie has the family stopping at a gas station and being greeted by a grizzly old man. Wolf Creek also has a similar gas station stopping scene. This movie has one of the characters walking to a big huge crater, Wolf Creek has the characters walking to a big huge crater. This movie has a family of crazy deformed mutants killing people stripping them of their valuables and junking their cars, Wolf Creek has a old crazy man that kills his victims strips them of their valuables and junks their cars, the list just goes on and on. Plus the deformed mutant in the wheelchair reminded me of the video "Rubber Johnny" by Aphex Twin.

title: Nothing New except some blood.
review: First of all I have seen the original hills have eyes and it was a decent movie for what it is. When I first sat down and the movie started I had a good feeling about this movie from the previews. Well it started off kinda slow, with very bad acting and dialog. This persisted throughout the movie with nothing that was too new from the original movie except some more blood and killing scenes. With his said the way the movie progressed was terrible and had no real flow to things. The movie barley kept my attention. I have never fell asleep in a movie before in my life and I had a hard time keeping my eyes open for this movie. The best part was the end when I was able to leave in disgust and remember why I hate remakes and this is another perfect example of a movie that did not need to be made again.

title: A great flick for some disturbance
review:
Me and my friend just came back from watching this movie and I gotta say we loved it. The movie is a combination of a few classics in the same genre. Those who liked Texas Chainsaw Massacre, Hostel, Breakdown and Toxic Avenger will like this one. The movie starts up with a strange and quiet desert. First you can think this is an average horror movie, but after 30-40 minutes or so, sh*t goes raw as hell. The middle scene is just classic to me, I won't go into details for you to enjoy it but it's just pure madness. You go out fu**ed up on this one. The movie is disturbing.

4/5 easily

title: Predictable in every sense
review: The film starts out as you would expect any normal cinematic piece falling under the horror / zombie horror genre to introduce itself. I have to admit though, not a huge fan of these type of films myself, I did find that becoming startled almost became the norm for the first fifteen minutes or so. The film takes numerous routes open to exploration, some unpredictable, others more obvious. But as the film went on I found myself wondering where it was going to go, and certain characters (one in particular) certainly showed they weren't going to be restricted by what you would typically expect capable when first making judgements on the characters. I have to say though by the end this particular novelty began to wear thin, and crossed over into unrealistic. Adrenaline is one thing, but it is arguable that determination beyond human capability was shown. Moreover, as the film came to a close the more typical expectations began to shine through. You find yourself saying "No, don't do that." and "What are you stupid?" just as in every other mediocre film of a similar sort, where you can see whats coming about 30 seconds to a minute beforehand. My opinion of the film was a lot higher half way through in comparison to that of the end. And I'm sitting here now reconsidering my score of 7, and trying to convince myself that it was overall enjoyable and worthwhile seeing...but it's not proving easy.

title: The Hills Have Eyes.... and murderous mutants with axes and other nasty weapons
review:
SLIGHT SPOILERS: I just came from seeing a sneak preview of The Hills Have Eyes and the first thing I have to say is that this movie beats Hostel easily for Most Brutal Movie of the year award. This movie is one rough ride and once it really gets going, it doesn't stop. I want to keep this review short but I will touch on a couple of things worth mentioning: - I felt very tense watching this. For the first hour or so, my stomach was twisted into a tight knot. It's been a while since a movie's done that to me. The suspense as things slowly unfold is extremely well done.

  • The acting is actually pretty good on all counts, especially in the case of Aaron Stanford who is excellent in this. The audience went berserk for him at one point and I was clapping along with everyone else, especially at this one point at the very end.


  • Some very sadistic violence. If watching well meaning, innocent people get it in different ways is not your thing, then look elsewhere. This is a film about tragedy and injustice and the film pulls no punches when it comes to dispatching people, mutated or not. Even after people are killed, they still get disrespected.


  • Great special effects. The make up on some of the characters is downright disturbing.


  • Director Aja more than made up for the piece of crap that was "Haute Tension".


  • The rape scene isn't as bad as you have been led to believe.


  • This movie suffers from one of those things I absolutely hate about horror movies: characters doing absolutely idiotic things. You know what I mean, going off to inspect things by yourself, leaving weapons near seemingly dead killers, etc, etc. It happens several times and each time it's just more annoying.


I really enjoyed this film and I think that word of mouth is going to carry this movie for a big opening weekend. This is one for the gorehounds and I honestly don't think that anyone with an appreciation for horror flicks will walk away disappointed.

In the end, I'm just happy that horror movies are beginning to get some balls again.

Strongly recommended.

RATING: ***1/2 out of *****.

title: same old story, but still fairly thrilling
review: I'm a little tired of the "Texas Chainsaw" template playing out ad nauseum. You know the story...wayward travelers end up stopping at a gas station, receiving misdirection from some creepy individual tied to a murderous clan, then end up victims of said clan. That's the biggest negative about this movie: it's old hat (except for a particularly upsetting mid-section). Acting by Shaw and Quinlan and the cast is solid, probably more likable and naturalistic than it needed to be. The direction is strong, the photography fantastic...it's a transporting film...there's just something a little uneven in the tone. Realistic humans, cartoonish villains...I think the Texas Chainsaw remake did this one better.

title: Pretty good remake
review:
I am something of a classic horror aficianodo and Wes Craven fan. I went into this film preparing to be disappointed and was pleasantly surprised. The film does a good job of being faithful to the original but adds some new aspects and updated special effects (but not too much to be over the top) to make the film good. I would still recommend the original, even though it is certainly dated in its special effects and limited by its shoe-string budget.

Make no doubt about it, the film is pretty intense, gory and brutal--definitely not for the faint of heart. It does, however, have its share of starts and I jumped a few times--which isn't easy to make me do.

Basically, the plot revolved around a typical middle class family which gets lost in the desert and is attacked by a feral family that lives in the hills. By the end, however, you are supposed to be asking yourself who the real savages are. In this respect, the re-makers stay true to the original film. In this version, however, we find out more about the feral family and why they are the way they are.

The film does a very good job at creating suspense and using subtle effects (sounds, music) to generate fear without necessarily utilizing typical gore. But if you like gore, you won't be disappionted either--lots of pickaxes through heads.

If you are into horror, I recommend.

title: I love horror, but this ain't it.
review:
Call me a hypocrite, but I can't help but think that while movies like Texas Chain Saw Massacre, Halloween and even Hostel have some redeeming value (whether social commentary or just plain entertainment), this one's pretty damn pointless.

The good -The character of Bobby (the teenage son) carries the film, and is pretty much a stand-in for the usual female hero that survives in the end. The kid who plays him did an excellent job and was very realistic, and though the character makes some stupid mistakes throughout, he never really has you yelling at the screen.

-The music from Tomandandy (who did Mean Creek's excellent music) was good, mostly country and B-movie instrumentals (like in the old Dogs of War trailer).

The bad -Pretty much everything else.

-The back story about the miners refusing to leave their homes and being mutated by government nuclear tests is weak. Hey guys, if they were going to do tests there, chances are the mines were barren and you'd be living in a ghost town anyway. This makes the "point" of the movie- that anyone can be driven to murder like a barbarian- kind of moot. The trailer family (who, by the way, are hardly the usual city folk pitted against murderous hillbillies-- they're gun-wielding republicans who would probably vote to let them keep their land, while liberals may have stopped the nuclear testing in the first place) is killing because half of them have been raped and killed and had their baby stolen, not because they were asked to move out of their dying desert town. Maybe if the government had taken the people's children away or not warned the residents in time... I dunno. After Wrong Turn, maybe we're just lucky to get ANY explanation for inbred hicks killing outsiders, other than the fact that, hey, they're inbred hicks and they've got a taste for blood.

-The rape scene and ensuing murders were needlessly graphic. Call me old-fashioned, but I like my horror movie serial killers impotent and sexual threats nonexistent or implied, like in Texas Chain Saw Massacre or A Nightmare on Elm Street. If Oscar-winning filmmakers have trouble not making rape scenes exploitative, Alexandre Aja sure isn't going to pull it off.

The ugly -The make-up is pretty good. The creepiest mutated people were really the ones who looked most human.

I'm not sure I would even call this movie horror. It's more 1970s exploitation (unsurprisingly) meets snuff flick, with better special effects. Plenty will be disgusted, few will be truly scared. I guess now I know how other people see horror movies that I love.

title: if stupid and scary is your thing...
review:
this is your movie.

it's chock full of BOO! and gore and all kinds of silly scary stuff, but if you haven't turned your brain off altogether, you too will be annoyed. it was fun, but not that fun.

the story (and movie) has been done before, and while this version is far more ookie and blood and gutsy, it's really no better than the first.

there are so many GIANT bad holes in this version that the audience was audibly laughing at things that they probably weren't supposed to.

all i gotta say, if they make a sequel starring "beast", i'm in, as he was arguably the most interesting, talented actor in the movie.

title: Finally a decent one.
review: A family decides to take a vacation to California. After stopping at a run down gas station and taking directions from a seemingly less than trustworthy individual, their innocent little family outing turns into a living hell. I think everyone has been waiting for a good horror film, in spite of the recent lack luster ones that have came out this year. Having never seen the original "The Hills Have Eyes" I couldn't tell you which one is better. This one definitely exceeded my expectations. I had an opportunity to see this at an advanced screening. It starts of a little on the slow side. Some of the characters are just strait up annoying starting off, so be prepared to be wishing death on some of them. When the action starts, it hits hard. You will find yourself pitying this poor family. The acting wasn't that bad surprisingly. If you are a fan of gore this movie offers some pretty good scenes. Nothing outstanding though. The suspense was a little mediocre. You have your typical "boo" type scares. You can see most of them coming. This movie's strength is in the situation this family is in. They start off not getting along very well, but after loosing some of their own they have to learn to get along as a family and fight for survival. I'll give the family dog kudos. You'll see what I mean.
